I'll move to UI for comment then.  They may be able to avoid causing a decoration on closed projects. However, there is nothing in the decoration API contract that says closed projects will never be decorated, so the decorator in question should really be handling the case more gracefully (check for closed projects and/or avoid logging).

Hi, I work on Subclipse -- where the user experiences the problem.

I am assuming that checking if a project is open before using every resource would be very expensive.

Also, any idea why I cannot duplicate this?  I have closed projects all the time and never get this.  What scenario triggers Eclipse to try to decorate closed projects?  If we knew that, maybe we could fix the problem in Subclipse easier.
